summary: Avian infectious bronchitis virus is an enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus with a genome length of approximately 27 kb. the 3′ end of the genome encodes four structural proteins; spike (S), envelope (E), membrane (M) and nucleocapsid (N) as well as several non-structural proteins. polyproteins are post-translationally cleaved into 15 non-structural proteins (nsps) key nsps encoded include a papain-like protease 2 (PLP2) within nsp 3, a main protease (Mpro) within nsp 5 and the RNA-dependent RNA-polymerase (RdRp) within nsps 11 and 12. different serotypes of field viruses and vaccine type viruses were selected to provide a wide variety of sequences potentially capable of contributing gene fragments to recombinants. results and Discussion 2.1. Sequence Analysis The full-length genomes of eight isolates of IBV were sequenced at 5 to 10 coverage, and the consensus sequences were assembled. 1–528 528 – 1–528 528 – 1–528 528 – 1–528 528 – 1–528 528 – 1a 528–12389 1,862 3953 529–12309 11781 3926 529–12387 11859 3952 529–12387 11859 3952 529–12330 11802 3933 529–12384 11856 3951 529–12390 11802 3933 5 195 64 Envelope 24221–24502 282 93 24133–24462 330 109 24186–24488 303 100 24222–24545 324 107 24150–24479 330 109 24219–24542 324 107 24228–24551 324 107 24225–24548 324 107 Membrane 24651–25175 525 174 24434–25111 678 225 24 36 249 82 25682–25930 249 82 25741–25989 249 82 25746–25994 249 82 Nucleocapsid 25923–27152 1230 409 25856–27085 1230 409 25901–27130 1230 409 25879–27111 1233 410 25873–27102 1230 409 25932–27161 1230 409 25937–27166 12 wild bird viruses isolated from a munia (MuniaCoV/HKUY13/09), thrush (ThrushCoV/HKU12/09) and bulbul (BulBulCoV/HKU11/09) formed a unique clade. this group might represent a new coronavirus genus provisionally designated Deltacoronavirus [18] s reduces mutat onal load, creates genetic variation, and can result in the emergence of new strains. recombination programs can be used to detect recombination without reference sequences. recombination programs can be used to detect recombination without reference sequences. recombination breakpoints a, genes and major and minor related sequences in other infectious bronchitis virus strains. some of the transferred fragments overlap suggesting that recombinations have occurred between recombinant viruses. transferred gene fragments with statistical support of >1 1012 are included in the table. Conn/Conn46/66 and Conn46/91 share the same recombination history (4 identical transferred fragments) the conn/Conn46/66 field virus was used to produce an attenuated live vaccine, which is currently used in commercial poultry. the FL/FL18288/71 virus also shares all 4 transferred fragments with the Conn viruses. it is well known that the Gray/Gray/60 virus is nephropathogenic, whereas the JMK/JMK/64 virus is strictly respirotropic. sequence differences in the 5′UTR, which is involved in replication of the viral genome, play a role in the different pathobiologies observed for these viruses. there is evidence that some transferred fragments in field viruses come from vaccines. no global hot-spot regions were observed in the 95% and 99% confidence thresholds. the detectable recombination breakpoint positions are shown at the top of the figure and were distributed throughout the genome with a relatively high number clustered just upstream of the S gene. that region also had the highest breakpoint count within the 99% local hot/cold-spot confidence interval. the nsp 3 encodes the protease PLP2 which cleaves nsps 2, 3, and 4 and an area with ADP-ribose 1′-phosphatase (ADRP) activity. the protease PLP2 has been shown to have deubi. the ADRP region of nsp 3 is conserved among coronaviruses. a recent study suggested a biological role for the coronavirus ADRP in modulating the expression of pro-inflammatory immune modulators such as interleukin-6. changes to the 3′UTR could affect replication efficiency and thus virulence of the virus. genome size, organization of the genome, and location and size of the open reading frames (ORFs) are listed in Table 1 for each of the viruses. 28 528 – 1–528 528 – 1a 528–12389 1,862 3953 529–12309 11781 3926 full-length genomes were aligned and phylogenetic trees were constructed using the Neighbor-joining, Minimum Evolution, Maximum Parsimony and UPGMA programs. the trees all had similar topology and bootstrap support, and a representative tree is shown in Figure 1. thrush (ThrushCoV/HKU12/09) and bulbul (BulBulCoV/HKU11/09) formed a unique clade. the remaining viruses separated into clades consisting of IBV isolates from the us and vaccine viruses, TCoV isolates, an IBV isolate from West Africa and IBV isolates from China and Taiwan. recombination programs can be used to detect recombination without reference sequences. the full-length genomes available in the database for CK/CH/EP3, CK/CH/p65, and Mass/Beaudette were excluded from the analysis. herein only represents sequences in other viruses that are most closely related to the sequence surrounding the transferred fragment (major sequence) and the sequence closely related to the transferred fragment (minor statistical support of >1 1012 are included in the table. major Sequence = Sequence closely related to the transferred fragment in the recombinant. the conn/Conn46/66 field virus was used to produce an attenuated live vaccine, which is currently used in commercial poultry. a recombination history is likely derived from the same parent virus suggesting that Conn/Conn46/91 is reisolated Conn vaccine derived from the conn virus. 'UTR is not found in Gray/Gray/60. it is well known that the Gray/Gray/60 virus is nephropathogenic. the JMK/JMK/64 virus is strictly respirotropic. sequence differences in the 5′UTR play a role in the different pathobiologies observed for these viruses. no global hot-spot regions were observed in the 95% and 99% confidence thresholds. a high number of breakpoints were also observed in the 1a region of the genome. nsp2, nsp3, nsp16 and spike genes were associated with the greatest number of transferred fragments. the nsp 3 encodes the protease PLP2 which cleaves nsps 2, 3, and 4 and an area with ADP-ribose 1′-phosphatase (ADRP) activity. the protease PLP2 has been shown to have deubiquinating-like activity. the ADRP region of nsp 3 is conserved among coronaviruses. a recent study suggested a biological role for the coronavirus ADRP in modulating the expression of pro-inflammatory immune modulators such as tumor necrosis factor alpha. evidence was obtained that recombination is occurring among avian coronavirus IBV isolates across their entire genome. every sequence included in the analysis was recognized as a potential recipient of horizontally acquired sequences at some point in its viral evolutionary past. breakpoints in the 1ab polyprotein gene have the potential to alter pathogenicity of the virus. Viruses and Viral RNA Extraction All of the viruses sequenced in this study were propagated in 9–11 day-old specific-pathogen-free embryonated eggs. total RNA was isolated from 200 L of allantoic fluid collected from the infected eggs using the high pure RNA Isolation Kit. the RT-PCR reaction was carried out using the TaKaRa RNA LA PCR kit (Takara Bio. Inc., Otsu, Shiga, Japan) the PCR products were cloned into the TOPOXL vector using the TOPOXL cloning kit. a 1/12-strength sequencing reaction on an ABI 3730 was used to sequence each clone from both the 5′ and 3′ ends. the reactions were prepared for sequencing by centrifugation through either a centri-sep column (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA) or using the Edge system (EdgeBio, Gaithersburg, MD, USA) assembly and analysis Chromatogram files and trace data were read and assembled using SeqMan Pro. genome annotation was conducted with seqBuilder (DNASTAR, Inc., Madison, WI, USA) each sequence was aligned to a representative genome; Mass/Mass41/41 (GenBank accession #AY851295), or CAL99/CAL99/99 (GenBank accession #AY514485) as a backbone for genome assembly. CK/CH/SC021202/02 (EU714029), CK/CH/ZJ971/97 (EU714028), CK/CH/BJ/97 (AY319651), CK/CH/SAIBK (DQ288927), CK/CH/LSD/051/06 (EU637854), CK/CH/DY07/07 (HM245923), CK/CH/CQ04-1/04 (HM245924), GA98 the IBV genomes were examined for recombination breakpoints using the Recombination Detection Program (RDP4, version 4, Simmonics, University of Warwick, Coventry, UK) unless otherwise stated, default settings were used in all of the programs. the specific algorithms used were RDP [40], GENECONV [41], BOOTSCAN/RESCAN [40], MAXIMUM CHI SQUARE [42], CHIMAERA [43], SISCAN changes in tree position of taxa supported at 70% bootstrap level for a 250 bp sequence window were examined at 100 bp intervals. phylogenetic compatibility matrix was constructed and used to examine the frequency and location of recombinations across the entire genome. 99% (upper) and 95% (lower) confidence threshold for globally significant breakpoint clusters was calculated. RT-PCR reaction was carried out using strand displacement RT-PCR or one step RT-PCR. amplification reactions were carried out using strand displacement RT-PCR or one step RT-PCR. agarose gel purified using the QIAquick gel extraction kit. the PCR products were cloned into the TOPOXL vector using the TOPOXL cloning kit. cloned cDNA fragments were isolated using an alkaline lysis method. the resulting cDNA was sequenced using the QIAquick gel extraction kit. the reactions were prepared for sequencing by centrifugation through either a centri-sep column (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA) or using the Edge system. GenBank accession numbers for full-length sequences used as reference in this study are: Mass/Mass41/41 (AY851295), Mass/H52 (EU817497), Ark-DPI-p11/81 (EU418976), Ark-DPI-p101/91 (EU418975), CAV/CAV99/99 (AY514485), CK/CH/EP3 (DQ001338), Mass/Beaudette (NC_001451), N we used Neighbor-net analysis to examine the IBV genomes for evidence of networked relationships and the pairwise homoplasy index (PHI) in SplitsTree (Version 4, Simmonics, University of Warwick, Coventry, UK) [20,38,39] to statistically determine the likelihood of recombination. detection methods using both simulated and empirical data showed that the results from only a single method were not very reliable. a window size of 60, BOOTSCAN window size was increased to 500, MAXCHI and CHIMAERA number of variable sites per window was increased to 120. the window sizes were increased from their default settings because IBV has a high mutation rate. 95% confidence threshold for global significant breakpoint clusters was calculated. 99% and 95% confidence intervals were calculated for local breakpoint clusters.
